definition:
*Elementary Functional Arithmetic*, or EFA, is a weak theory of
arithmetic created by removing induction from Peano Arithmetic. Because
it lacks induction, axioms defining exponentiation must be added.

-   $\forall x (x'\neq 0)$ ($0$ is the first number)

-   $\forall x,y (x'=y'\rightarrow x=y)$ (the successor function is
    one-to-one)

-   $\forall x (x+0=x)$ ($0$ is the additive identity)

-   $\forall x,y(x+y'=(x+y)')$ (addition is the repeated application of
    the successor function)

-   $\forall x(x\cdot 0=0)$

-   $\forall x,y(x\cdot(y')=x\cdot y+x$ (multiplication is repeated
    addition)

-   $\forall x(\neg (x<0))$ ($0$ is the smallest number)

-   $\forall x,y(x<y'\leftrightarrow x<y\vee x=y)$

-   $\forall x(x^0=1)$

-   $\forall x(x^{y'}=x^y\cdot x)$
